name: (3E)-Hex-3-en-1-ol

Generally, the introduction of a double bond slightly increases the melting point due to more restricted rotation around the bond, but this effect is limited in long-chain alkenes; we can estimate this to be around +5°C. The hydroxyl group, on the other hand, has a much stronger impact due to hydrogen bonding capabilities which significantly increase the melting point. In a molecule with a hydroxyl group, the effect can be around +30°C. Thus, the sum of effects of the double bond and hydroxyl group combined suggests an increase in the melting point.

- The double bond in the alkene (C=C) can slightly increase the melting point due to the rigidity it introduces, but the effect is less pronounced than that of the hydroxyl group. This can be estimated to increase the melting point by about +5°C.
